security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill containing markdown files with IT operations guidance. Static scanner flagged 720 pattern matches but all are FALSE POSITIVES triggered by legitimate sysadmin examples. No executable code, no network calls, no file system access. Pure prompt-based skill for Claude to provide IT operations expertise.

content.value_statement: IT teams struggle with unreliable services, slow incident response, and manual processes. This skill provides frameworks for monitoring, incident management, automation, and disaster recovery to ensure service reliability and operational excellence.
actual_capabilities: Implement monitoring and alerting strategies with SLI/SLO/SLA frameworks
Guide incident response with structured triage, escalation, and post-mortems
Create backup and disaster recovery plans with RPO/RTO definitions
Develop automation scripts for server provisioning and configuration management
Perform capacity planning and infrastructure cost optimization
Design runbooks and documentation for operational procedures
limitations: Does not execute commands on external systems
Does not access or modify production infrastructure
Does not integrate with specific monitoring tools directly
Does not replace human judgment for critical decisions

use_cases.title: Establish SRE practices
use_cases.description: Define SLIs, SLOs, and error budgets for services while implementing proactive monitoring and incident response workflows.

use_cases.title: Build operational frameworks
use_cases.description: Create incident management processes, backup strategies, and capacity planning procedures for the organization.

use_cases.title: Automate infrastructure tasks
use_cases.description: Develop automation scripts, configuration management playbooks, and self-healing systems to reduce manual toil.

prompt_templates.title: Monitor setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me design a monitoring strategy for a web application including what metrics to track, alerting thresholds, and dashboard design principles.

prompt_templates.title: Incident response
prompt_templates.prompt: Walk me through the incident response process for a production outage including severity classification, roles, and communication templates.

prompt_templates.title: DR planning
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a disaster recovery plan for our database servers including RPO/RTO definitions, backup strategies, and failover procedures.

prompt_templates.title: Automation project
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me identify high-value automation opportunities in our operations workflow and design an automation script for server health checks.

output_examples.input: Our production database is experiencing high CPU usage. What should we do?
output: Check monitoring dashboards for CPU trends and identify peak usage times
Review running queries for slow or resource-intensive operations
Verify if recent deployments or configuration changes correlate with the issue
Consider immediate mitigation through query optimization or temporary scaling
Plan long-term solutions including query tuning, read replicas, or instance upgrades

output_examples.input: We need to set up on-call rotations for our team of 5 engineers
output: Define escalation policy with clear levels: L1 first responder, L2 team lead, L3 manager
Create rotation schedule using tools like PagerDuty or Opsgenie
Establish response time targets: acknowledge within 15 minutes, resolve within 4 hours
Document runbooks for common alerts to reduce mean time to recovery
Schedule weekly handoff meetings to transfer context between on-call engineers

best_practices: Implement monitoring before incidents occur rather than reactively adding alerts
Conduct blameless post-mortems focused on system improvements not individual blame
Automate repetitive tasks to reduce toil and free time for engineering work
anti_patterns: Ignoring warning signs until small incidents become major outages
Skipping post-mortems or failing to implement action items from reviews
Using manual processes for frequent tasks that should be automated

faq.question: What monitoring tools does this skill support?
faq.answer: The skill covers Prometheus, Grafana, Datadog, New Relic, ELK Stack, and cloud-native monitoring solutions with implementation examples.

faq.question: Can this skill help with Kubernetes operations?
faq.answer: Yes, the automation and monitoring guides include Kubernetes examples for operators, Prometheus monitoring, and self-healing systems.

faq.question: Does this skill execute any code on my systems?
faq.answer: No, this skill only provides guidance and examples. All code snippets are educational references for you to adapt and run in your own environment.

faq.question: How do I handle on-call rotations effectively?
faq.answer: The incident management guide covers on-call best practices including escalation policies, rotation schedules, and tools like PagerDuty integration.

faq.question: What is the difference between monitoring and observability?
faq.answer: Monitoring answers is the system up with predefined dashboards. Observability helps investigate why the system is behaving this way through metrics, logs, and traces.

faq.question: How does this compare to SRE practices?
faq.answer: This skill incorporates SRE principles including error budgets, toil reduction, automation-first approaches, and service level objectives aligned with business needs.
